import numpy as np # linear algebra

import seaborn as sns 
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

source.7906e2a7:
from scipy.stats import shapiro

SPACE      = 30
WIDTH      = 20
HEIGHT     = 5
MAX_ORD    = 7
MAX_SAMPLE = 5000

def analyze(frame, column):
    # Title
    print(f"{'Column'.rjust(SPACE)} : {column}")
    
    # Missing values
    print(f"{'Missing values'.rjust(SPACE)} : {frame[column].isna().sum()}")
    
    # Numerical variables
    if frame[column].dtypes != 'O' and len(frame[column].unique()) > MAX_ORD:
        # Descriptive stats
        print(f"{'Correlation(target)'.rjust(SPACE)} : {frame[column].corr(frame[TARGET])}")
        print(f"{'Mean'.rjust(SPACE)} : {frame[column].mean()}")
        print(f"{'Min'.rjust(SPACE)} : {frame[column].min()}")
        print(f"{'Q1'.rjust(SPACE)} : {frame[column].quantile(0.25)}")
        print(f"{'Median'.rjust(SPACE)} : {frame[column].median()}")
        print(f"{'Q3'.rjust(SPACE)} : {frame[column].quantile(0.75)}")
        print(f"{'Max'.rjust(SPACE)} : {frame[column].max()}")
        print(f"{'Var'.rjust(SPACE)} : {frame[column].var()}")
        print(f"{'Std'.rjust(SPACE)} : {frame[column].std()}")
        
        stats, p_value = shapiro(frame[column].sample(n=MAX_SAMPLE))
        print(f"{'Normal distrib.'.rjust(SPACE)} : {round(stats, 3), round(p_value, 3)}")
        
        # Distribution
        plt.figure(figsize=(WIDTH, HEIGHT))
        sns.histplot(data=frame, x=column, hue=TARGET)
        plt.title(f"Distribution of {column}")
        plt.show()
        
        # Plot one against the other
        plt.figure(figsize=(WIDTH, HEIGHT))
        sns.boxenplot(data=train, x=TARGET, y=column)
        plt.title(f"{TARGET} vs {column}")
        plt.show()
    
    # Categorical variables
    else:
        # Count plot
        plt.figure(figsize=(WIDTH, HEIGHT))
        sns.countplot(data=train, x=column, hue=TARGET)
        plt.title(f"{TARGET} vs {column}")
        plt.show()

source.27e15fa2:
#Musical trends (1950 – 2019), by Kevin Stevens, August 5, 2020.

What does Spotify’s tell us about how musical feeling has (Worsened my opinion)?

"AI calculated metrics give us an understanding of the 50m+ tracks on the service by revealing information such as how danceable a song is, how positive it is or how much energy it has."

"The data from ‘All Out 50s’ shows that the bulk of the tracks sit just above 0.5 suggesting that most songs did not really deviate too much in terms of danceability – but there are outliers which show some did break away from the norm. Elvis Presley’s ‘Return to Sender’ is the highest outlier for danceability in ‘All Out 50s’."

https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/change-musical-mood-1950-2019-kevin-stevens?articleId=6696344296271962113

#Elvis is Not an Outlier.

He is Elvis, not an Outlier. He is a King! "Elvis Presley is the undisputed King of Rock and Roll. In 1954, Elvis Presley kicked off a musical revolution by modernizing traditional genres such as blues, country and bluegrass."

https://www.elvis.com.au/presley/elvis-presley-the-king-of-rock-n-roll.shtml#:~:text=Elvis%20Presley%20is%20the%20undisputed,as%20blues%2C%20country%20and%20bluegrass.
